tutorial.name: Sub bass
tutorial.description: The Rumble, usually out of human's hearing range and tend to be felt more than heard, providing a sense of power.

tutorial.name: Bass
tutorial.description: Determins how "fat" or "thin" the sound is, boosting around 250hz tend to add a feeling of warmth. If you're a bass head you most likely like this range.

tutorial.name: Lower Mids
tutorial.description: Low order harmonics of most instruments, generally viewed as the bass presence range. Boosting a signal around 300 Hz adds clarity to the bass and lower-stringed instruments. Too much boost around 500 Hz can make higher-frequency instruments sound muffled.

tutorial.name: Midrange
tutorial.description: The midrange determines how prominent an instrument is in the mix. Boosting around 1000 Hz can give instruments a horn-like quality. Excess output at this range can sound tinny and may cause ear fatigue.

tutorial.name: Upper Mids
tutorial.description: The high midrange is responsible for the attack on percussive and rhythm instruments. If boosted, this range can add presence. However, too much boost around the 3 kHz range can cause listening fatigue.

tutorial.name: Presence
tutorial.description: The presence range is responsible for the clarity and definition of a sound. Over-boosting can cause an irritating, harsh sound. Cutting in this range makes the sound more distant and transparent.

tutorial.name: Brilliance
tutorial.description: The brilliance range is composed entirely of harmonics and is responsible for sparkle and air of a sound. Over boosting in this region can accentuate hiss and cause ear fatigue.

tutorial.name: Non-Confidence Interval
tutorial.description: An interval where relative comparisons between measurements are not problematic, but unreliable due to the nature of IEC 60318-4 (711) measurement equipment. This is where the over-represented resonance peak of 711 begins, and is also the main reason why FR measurements obtained by controlling the insertion depth are slightly different from what is perceived due to the inconsistent insertion depth of the earphones in real listening environments.

accessories.content: This graph database is maintained by SilicaGel. All measurements are done using 'IEC 60318-4' compliant ear simulator. This web software is based on a HarutoHiroki's modified version of CrinGraph, which was originally developed by Marshall Lochbaum

main.label: label
